newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan central bank to keep money policy unchanged.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan central bank to keep money policy unchanged.

text.p: Taiwan's central bank governor Sheu Yuan-dong said on Thursday it would maintain its longstanding stable-to-loose monetary policy.
"The central bank will keep its stable-to-loose, but not too loose, monetary policy," Sheu told a news conference after the bank's board meeting.
Sheu said the current monetary policy will enable the central bank to guide financial stability as well as economic growth.
"The central bank will fully provide funds for normal economic activities and it will continue to mildly mop up liquidity if banking system's liquidity becomes too loose," Sheu said.
Sheu said the central bank had no intention to interfere with the foreign exchange market.
"The operation of the foreign exchange market is currently very sound. There are no unusual factors of interference," Sheu said.
"The central bank will respect market forces and let the market's supply and demand determine the rate of the Taiwan dollar," he added.
The Taiwan dollar has fallen recently after the murder of a famous actress's daughter triggered mass protests which dealers feared may lead to foreign funds outflow.

The murder also has led to calls for a cabinet reshuffle and even the resignation of Premier Lien Chan. President lee Teng-hui has declined Lien's resignation offer but has asked Lien to launch a partial reshuffle of the cabinet.

Ma Ying-jeou, a minister without portfolio and one of the most popular members of the ruling Nationalist Party, said on Thursday he would resign due to "change of political ethics, obstacles in reforms and growing public discontent."
Sheu, however, said the recent political developments had not impacted the financial sphere.
"The recent political events have not had an influence on the financial markets," Sheu said.
Sheu added that the central bank would not formulate its monetary policy based solely on stock market performance.
"The stock market is only one part of the financial market. What we are concerned about is overall financial stability and economic growth," Sheu said.
Private analysts had said that the recent torrential trade volumes registered in the stock market may prompt the central bank to launch tightening measures to curb liquidity.
